overview_of_class: When ideological tensions flared between the United States and Soviet Union after World War Two, the world braced for another major military conflict. Although a series of political and military crises ensued, the Cold War was largely fought in the realm of culture. Students will explore how film, dance, and sports became weapons of war during this quest for ideological and cultural superiority. This course will cover the Americanization of Postwar Europe, the Red Scare and Containment, the fear of mutually-assured destruction, the long-term effects of "the Thaw," and the dissolution of the Soviet Union while searching for insight into the period from films like The Day the Earth Stood Still, Dr. Strangelove, and Rambo. Dance diplomacy and historic Olympic match-ups between American and Soviet athletes will also inform the ways in which we assess the experience and outcome of the Cold War. Ultimately, this course offers an explanation of the major currents of the Cold War while introducing students to the methods used by cultural historians.
